I hear all the Democrats talking about the bad economic times, and then they blame it on Bush. The thing that gets me really mad is when they say that Clinton handed Bush a good economy. That is a lie. The recession started in the last quarter of his term. He handed Bush a recession. 
 
 Now if you Democrats want to talk about bad economic times you should mention when they got bad. 
 
 It's a great tactic...they're making it all sound horrible and like it's Bush's fault. I'm sorry...the tech bubble bursted. Things start looking up and we have a horrible terrorist attack. It is not Bush's fault that things aren't going so well right now. At least Bush has done more than throw a few cruise missiles at abandoned training camps.

post_info.post_title: Democrats Need To Stop the Lies

This economic roller coast we are now on I blame on one person: Ronald Reagan.
 
 Ronald Reagan, his ecomic policies, his economic boom, and Greenspan (Reagan appointee). Started this roller coaster back in the late 80's and we are all just along for the ride. Alot of the CEO philosophy that got us intro trouble today started durring Reagan. By no means am I bashing Reagan. He started the longest economic growth period in the history of the US. Those things don't last for ever, we are just in a down turn part of the roller coaster ride that we can not get off.
I think the bubble could have lasted longer if Cliton had similar policies.
Because we all know that when Clinton was prez the economic slowed to a crawl...
It did after he left... I think his success was only a result of the Reagan tax cuts. You'll disagree though.

its funny how conservatives blame clinton for the economy when clinton really enacted a classic conservative economic program. He lowered taxes (on the middle class, but still lowered them), and balanced the budget, achieving the surpluses that reagan (and both bushs for that matter) never dreamed of. Fiscal responsibilty USED TO BE a conservative issue, now the liberals have taken it over (which i find endlessly amusing). Didn't it used to be conservatives that were always cautioning not to spend money we didn't have? Now the biggest deficit hawk in the presidential race is Howard Dean.

But these surpluses are justified and the fault of both parties.
 
 Under Reagan Democrats and Republicans wouldn't cut anything out of the budgets and we build up our defences. The Soviets feel, so that was worth it. 
 
 Now we are in a time of war and have a need for more money to secure ourselves. We'll have that deficit... 
 
 Clinton had the most deployments under a president, yet he slashed the number of servicemen by 45% and cut the navy almost in half. Now Democrats are saying we don't have enough troops and we're too widespread, but they don't want to get on Clinton's case.
 
 Ugh... say it everyone! Just say it! Hypocrisy!

And I think people are seeing this. The Democrats are playing politics and not doing the best thing for our nation. 
 
 The Republicans could have blocked a Clinton judicial appointment, but they didn't. This guy did most of the stuff that the Democrats say Estrada is doing... not handing over documents, answering some questions, etc.
 
 Then we have all the support for Clinton actions in Iraq, the Balkans, everywhere else he took us, yet now Bush doesn't have that support. 
 
 Conservatives are playing the tape, reading the quotes, and Democrats are going to lose favor. This game of politics is really going to hut.

OK, your analysis on the current deficit is flawed on a couple of accounts. You say the war on terror requires money. Yes, you're right. But it doesn't require $3 trillion dollars in tax cuts, and that is what is creating most of the deficit, not wartime spending. In fact, the CBO projected 10 year deficit (which is a multi-trillion dollar figure) doesn't even take into account the cost of the war with Iraq. So it's clear that the entity that is causing the deficit is tax cuts, not war spending. In fact, Bush has been prioritizing tax cuts over defense spending. Let's examine how:
 Immediately after 9/11, congress approved 20 billion dollars to shore up our immediate security concerns. After that, House Appropriations committee chair Bill Young and ranking minority member David Obey examined where we were still vulnerable, and bipartisanly (remember, its one republican and one democrat) said that we needed $10 billion more to provide for "computer upgrades for the FBI, improved security for ports and nuclear facilities, new customs agents, and other top homeland security priorities" (New Republic 3/3/03). When they proposed this to Bush, he said that Mitch Daniels, his budget director said that the original $20 bil. was adequete, and he would VETO THE BILL if it contained more than 20 bil. in spending. Appealing to party discpline, the extra 10 bil. wasn't allowed to come to a vote by house republican leaders. The question that jumps immediately to mind is why his budget director was telling him what is and is not adequete for homeland security. but let's continue.
 The impact of Bush refusing to allow for the extra money and security is:
 "President Bush vetoed several specific (and relatively cost-effective) measures proposed by Congress that would have addressed critical national vulnerabilities. As a result, the country remains more vulnerable than it should be today," February Report, Brookings Institution.
 A December 2002 report by the Council on Foreign Relations concurs: "America remains dangerously unprepared to prevent and respond to a catastrophic terrorist attack on U.S. soil." 
 Moving further:
 Spencer Abraham, Bush's secratary of energy, was alarmed that his department didn't have enough funds to protect against a terrorist STEALING AND SETTING OFF A NUKE. He writes "[T]he Department now is unable to meet the next round of critical security mission requirements. ... Failure to support these urgent security requirements is a risk that would be unwise," and requests 379.7 million dollars to defend against this. the administration gives him 26.4 million, 7% of the requested amount.
 The list of needed security issues that Bush refuses to fund are endless. The New Republic 3/3/03 outlines: "The list of improvements Bush declined to fund included more secure barriers and fences, computer improvements to defend against hackers, equipment to detect explosives in packages and vehicles entering department sites, and a reduction in the overall number of sites that store bomb-grade plutonium and uranium."
 Nor is Bush's reluctance to spend money to defend America limited to domestic concerns. the NR on 9/16/02 writes that when the US sought to airlift out enriched uranium from Serbia (where it posed a definite security risk) it had to be funded BY PRIVATE DONATIONS! Does Bush allocate more funds to the program that handles this? Nope. Last year he tried to cut its funding by 5%.
 Bush promises more funding to local police and fire depts., specifically to the tune of $3.5 billion in new money. The amount he gets around to giving? 700 million dollars, 20% of the promised amount.
 port security is another matter. Of the containers that make their way through our ports, though, only one in 50 is ever searched. As Stephen Flynn, a former Coast Guard commander who directed the Council on Foreign Relations' homeland security report, told a TV interviewer last month, "We have virtually no security there." The Coast Guard has estimated it would cost $1 billion immediately and another $4.5 billion over the next nine years to make domestic ports sufficiently secure. But, since September 11, they've received just $318 million.
 The INS requested a relatively paltry 52 mil. to hire new agents: turned down.
 (Thanks to the New Republic 3/3/03 for providing virtually all of the sources. The article "the 9/10 president" should be an essential read)
 So if Bush refuses to spend the money on homeland security, where is it going? Answer: Tax cuts. Bush cares more about his 3 trillion+ dollars in total tax cuts than he does about homeland security. This is the lie that needs to be refuted.
 
 Phew, that took awhile. And your statement that republicans never stopped clinton's appointees is blantantly false and you know it. Orrin Hatch took the judge confirmation fight to a whole new level. Clinton could barely push any of his judges through.
They still passed 60% of them. Bush has only got around 30% through.

And the Republicans had times when they could block, but they didn't... they let the judge through. 
 
 I really don't mind the Estrada thing... it's going to hurt them more the longer it goes. Hello Hispanic people! Welcome to the party!

If it wasn't for the fact that a) the confirmation of one judge isn't going to make or break politics for most hispanics and b) the nation's largest hispanicamerican groups oppose Estrada I'd be inclined to agree with you. Actually, the hispanics ARE trending rightward.
 
 You still have yet to defend Bush's egregious prioritization of tax cuts over defense and security.
One of his advisors told him that was bad...he listens to what they say. Most of them mist have had some reason... look deeper into the bill.

You're right, one of his advisors DID say it was bad: Mitch Daniels, his BUDGET DIRECTOR! What authority does he have on issues of national security? None at all. He's just looking at the price tag. And when Sec. of Energy Spencer Abraham squares off against Daniels on whether or not the dept. that safeguards our nukes has enough money to prevent them FROM BEING STOLEN, I say a) Abraham gets the nod and b) Even if by default he isn't more qualified, discretion is the better part of valor and in any event its STILL a more important priority than yet more tax cuts.
 
 Besides that "I'm sure he had his reasons" excuse would never cut it if it was a liberal president, and you know it.
There was probably something in the bill... some sort of attachment maybe?

Actually, when Obey and Thomas presented the bill to the president, they promised to remove any proposal in it he didn't like. He just said he wouldn't spend a penny more than he already had authorized, so none of it was ok.
It's one bill... calm down. Or should I lock myself in a closet?
Its not one bill, its one issue: The safety of America from terrorist attacks. If Bush is preventing that from occuring, then we need someone who will make America safe (Bob Graham! Bob Graham!)
No! Not him! Bob is evil... Hey, Bob, you're losing the Hispanic vote! HA HA! You won't be Senator for long... blasted Florida Democrats...
I thought you'd LIKE graham. He's even more hawkish than Bush is.
-_- Hawkish? Why do you think that matters... :P

 No

OK.......Broker.......helpppppp.............he's making me start to change my mindddd!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! lol Seriously though this has been pretty good. dsa, you are very persuasive! Albert, can you post the statistics on Clinton as well?

Democrats lieing? What about all the lies the Republishyts told? These Democrats are trying to save our country from the evil clutches of the GOP, and you go on the internet and start bashing them!? God Bless the Democrats!
 
 (If God is real that is)

The thing that gets me really mad is when they say that Clinton handed Bush a good economy. That is a lie. The recession started in the last quarter of his term. He handed Bush a recession. 

 
 Nonsense. The most you can say is that Clinton handed a recession to his legitimate successor, not to Bush. Bush stole the Presidency, and got everything that came with it. If you break into someone's house and eat a spoiled sandwich from his fridge, you cannot blame him for your food poisoning.
 
 In any case, Bush's economic policies are terrible. Reagan could at least honestly believe in trickle-down, as there was no previous experience with Reaganomics. Bush cannot.

Bush didn't steal the presidency, like it or not. He won, and every independent recount I've seen shows that he won. 
 
 Reagan had the greatest period of extended economic prosperity... ever.

Bush didn't steal the presidency, like it or not. He won, and every independent recount I've seen shows that he won. 

 
 Typical Republican lie. Recount results are public and we all know that Gore won. Bush is a completely illegitimate White House squatter.
 
 
Reagan had the greatest period of extended economic prosperity... ever. 

 
 Reagan had the greatest recession since WWII and the greatest increase of public debt in history. To his credit, he also led one of the best tax reforms in the history of the world, but it was so good only because it was a bitter compromise between his administration and the Democrat-controlled Congress.
 
 Clinton had the greatest perios of extended economic prosperity.

Oh really? Where was I when this came out? The recounts I've read about give Bush a 300- 1,500 vote lead. 
 
 He certainly recovered from that recession, didn't he? And that debt was caused by Congress. Reagan was concerned about it, but both parties refused to cut spending. 
 
 It was Reagan...

\
 
 Clinton had the greatest perios of extended economic prosperity.

 
 
 For one reason and one reason only though, it was the software and computer boom, something Clinton had nothing to do with, he just so happened to be in office at the time. Technology advanced itself faster in his 8 years then any other time in history, thats why the economy surged so well under Clinton, but it wasn't he who really did anything.
Don't forget that he had a Republican congress watching him...

Oh really? Where was I when this came out? The recounts I've read about give Bush a 300- 1,500 vote lead.
 
 
 Don't be ridiculous. Even the recounts under the pro-Bush Florida SC rules produced anywhere between a several hundred vote win for Bush and an extremely tight win for Gore. But when all votes are included according to Florida law, it was a 4-digit win for Gore.
 
 
He certainly recovered from that recession, didn't he? And that debt was caused by Congress. Reagan was concerned about it, but both parties refused to cut spending. 
 
 It was Reagan... 

 
 He did not need to recover from the recession, he did not feel it. And many people who felt it never recovered from it.
 
 The Congress was of course also responsible for the high deficits. But the same Democrats controlled the Congress during the Carter administration and during the first two years of the Clinton administration, yet the deficits were not nearly as bad as under Reagan and Bush.
 
 (I won't even mention that for 6 of Reagan's 8 years the Senate was Republican-controlled. The Senate is admittedly unimportant in the budget game.)
Well if you say you won't mention it, don't. Liberals, what are you going to do with them.............

For one reason and one reason only though, it was the software and computer boom, something Clinton had nothing to do with, he just so happened to be in office at the time. Technology advanced itself faster in his 8 years then any other time in history, thats why the economy surged so well under Clinton, but it wasn't he who really did anything.

 
 Unlike Reagan, who made wine from water and brought the dead back to life, right? emoticon_xclown

post_info.post_title: How far does the Republican hypocrisy go?

Again, please tell me where I was when this happened. I have NEVER heard of these recounts you speak of... are you talking about how Gore would have lead if he succeeded in having the military votes thrown out?

I should add that the problems were in the Democratic counties... have you seen those election boards in recount action? If you had a few votes for Democrats it could be declared a Democratic voting pattern and every vote on the ballot goes to the Democrat.

Again, please tell me where I was when this happened. I have NEVER heard of these recounts you speak of... are you talking about how Gore would have lead if he succeeded in having the military votes thrown out?

 
 No, I am talking about "overvotes" that were invalidated because they had Gore both marked/punched and "Gore" in the write-in slot. And ditto for Bush.
 
 Gore never even tried to have the invalid military votes thrown out (and there weren't more than a few hundred of those). But are you saying it was legitimate to count those?

I should add that the problems were in the Democratic counties... 

 
 Another lie. The biggest problem was in the heavily Republican Duval county (Jacksonville and its suburbs), where up to 20% of the votes in black precincts were invalidated.
 
 
have you seen those election boards in recount action?
 
 
 Yes I did.
 
 
If you had a few votes for Democrats it could be declared a Democratic voting pattern and every vote on the ballot goes to the Democrat. 

 
 Another lie. Based on everything I saw (and you could have only seen the same coverage), those people were working diligently and scrupulously. The only problem that ever happened in a recount room was when the Republican thugs broke in.

Yes he did... he went to court to try to have them thrown out.
 
 The majority of problems were in Democratic counties.
 
 Living in Florida, I saw a lot of coverage. And I watched the election boards on TV do it. When someone challenged the method, they were ejected from the room.

Yes he did... he went to court to try to have them thrown out.

 
 Oh yes? Which court? What case in the court record?
 
 
The majority of problems were in Democratic counties.

 
 Well, I told you precisely where the biggest problem was. When you challenge facts, you need to at least provide some alternative facts. Repeating what you said before does not add to your argument.
 
 
When someone challenged the method, they were ejected from the room. 

 
 And what do you think should be done when someone interferes with officials doing their job?

I don't know... this was years ago.
 
 I said Democratic counties at first, you gave a Republican, so I said most of the problems were in Democratic counties. 
 
 Well, when you decide by the first few votes that it's a Democratic voting pattern...

I don't know... this was years ago.

 
 This was just 2.5 years ago, plus all info is publicly available. It's OK if you don't know, but then you didn't know it yesterday, when you made the claim, either.
 
 
I said Democratic counties at first, you gave a Republican, so I said most of the problems were in Democratic counties. 

 
 I gave you specifics - Duval County. Want more specifics? 4967 undervotes and 21942 overvotes in that county (out of 291,626 votes cast). Which Democratic county was a bigger problem?
 
 
Well, when you decide by the first few votes that it's a Democratic voting pattern... 

 
 Repeating a lie does not make it any more true.
